content: Sam Altman hired Peter Steinberger, the creator of OpenClaw, an open-source AI agent that controls computers and performs jobs.
OpenAI quietly launched an enterprise agent platform the week before hiring Peter Steinberger.
Anthropic engineers have been embedded inside Goldman Sachs for six months, building autonomous AI agents for accounting, compliance, and onboarding tasks.
Goldman Sachs refers to the autonomous AI agents built by Anthropic as "digital co-workers."
Anthropic's business model focuses on technical end-users like developers, researchers, and enterprise teams, securing deals for custom, private, enterprise-grade AI solutions.
OpenAI's business model is characterized by mass distribution, exemplified by ChatGPT's rapid growth through public release rather than enterprise sales.
Sam Altman's strategy is to make custom enterprise AI contracts unnecessary by commoditizing AI agent technology for widespread use.
OpenClaw is an autonomous AI agent that can control an entire computer, performing tasks like reading emails, writing code, browsing the web, and negotiating deals.
Peter Steinberger, OpenClaw's creator, predicts that "OpenClaw-style agents will kill 80% of apps," a prediction now effectively OpenAI's roadmap.

Goldman Sachs' AI agents complete work rather than just answering questions, handling tasks like reconciling transactions, flagging discrepancies, filing settlements, parsing client passports, running compliance checks, and generating onboarding files.
